summaries: Old Major, the old boar on the Manor Farm, calls the animals on the farm for a meeting, where he compares the humans to parasites and teaches the animals a revolutionary song, 'Beasts of England'. When Major dies, two young pigs, Snowball and Napoleon, assume command and turn his dream into a philosophy. The animals revolt and drive the drunken and irresponsible Mr Jones from the farm, renaming it "Animal Farm". They adopt Seven Commandments of Animal-ism, the most important of which is, "All animals are equal". Snowball attempts to teach the animals reading and writing; food is plentiful, and the farm runs smoothly. The pigs elevate themselves to positions of leadership and set aside special food items, ostensibly for their personal health. Napoleon takes the pups from the farm dogs and trains them privately. Napoleon and Snowball struggle for leadership. When Snowball announces his plans to build a windmill, Napoleon has his dogs chase Snowball away and declares himself leader. Napoleon enacts changes to the governance structure of the farm, replacing meetings with a committee of pigs, who will run the farm. Using a young pig named Squealer as a "mouthpiece", Napoleon claims credit for the windmill idea. The animals work harder with the promise of easier lives with the windmill. After a violent storm, the animals find the windmill annihilated. Napoleon and Squealer convince the animals that Snowball destroyed it, although the scorn of the neighbouring farmers suggests that its walls were too thin. Once Snowball becomes a scapegoat, Napoleon begins purging the farm with his dogs, killing animals he accuses of consorting with his old rival. He and the pigs abuse their power, imposing more control while reserving privileges for themselves and rewriting history, villainising Snowball and glorifying Napoleon. Squealer justifies every statement Napoleon makes, even the pigs' alteration of the Seven Commandments of Animalism to benefit themselves. 'Beasts of England' is replaced by an anthem glorifying Napoleon, who appears to be adopting the lifestyle of a man. The animals remain convinced that they are better off than they were when under Mr Jones. Squealer abuses the animals' poor memories and invents numbers to show their improvement. Mr Frederick, one of the neighbouring farmers, attacks the farm, using blasting powder to blow up the restored windmill. Though the animals win the battle, they do so at great cost, as many, including Boxer the workhorse, are wounded. Despite his injuries, Boxer continues working harder and harder, until he collapses while working on the windmill. Napoleon sends for a van to take Boxer to the veterinary surgeon's, explaining that better care can be given there. Benjamin, the cynical donkey, who "could read as well as any pig", notices that the van belongs to a knacker, and attempts to mount a rescue; but the animals' attempts are futile. Squealer reports that the van was purchased by the hospital and the writing from the previous owner had not been repainted. He recounts a tale of Boxer's death in the hands of the best medical care. Years pass, and the pigs learn to walk upright, carry whips and wear clothes. The Seven Commandments are reduced to a single phrase: "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others". Napoleon holds a dinner party for the pigs and the humans of the area, who congratulate Napoleon on having the hardest-working but least fed animals in the country. Napoleon announces an alliance with the humans, against the labouring classes of both "worlds". He abolishes practices and traditions related to the Revolution, and changes the name of the farm to "The Manor Farm". The animals, overhearing the conversation, notice that the faces of the pigs have begun changing. During a poker match, an argument breaks out between Napoleon and Mr Pilkington, and the animals realise that the faces of the pigs look like the faces of humans, and no one can tell the difference between them. The pigs Snowball, Napoleon, and Squealer adapt Old Major's ideas into an actual philosophy, which they formally name Animalism. Soon after, Napoleon and Squealer indulge in the vices of humans (drinking alcohol, sleeping in beds, trading). Squealer is employed to alter the Seven Commandments to account for this humanisation, an allusion to the Soviet government's revising of history in order to exercise control of the people's beliefs about themselves and their society. The original commandments are: # Whatever goes upon two legs is an enemy. # Whatever goes upon four legs, or has wings, is a friend. # No animal shall wear clothes. # No animal shall sleep in a bed. # No animal shall drink alcohol. # No animal shall kill any other animal. # All animals are equal. Later, Napoleon and his pigs secretly revise some commandments to clear them of accusations of law-breaking (such as "No animal shall drink alcohol" having "to excess" appended to it and "No animal shall sleep in a bed" with "with sheets" added to it). The changed commandments are as follows, with the changes bolded: * 4 No animal shall sleep in a bed with sheets. * 5 No animal shall drink alcohol to excess. * 6 No animal shall kill any other animal without cause. Eventually these are replaced with the maxims, "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others", and "Four legs good, two legs better!" as the pigs become more human. This is an ironic twist to the original purpose of the Seven Commandments, which were supposed to keep order within Animal Farm by uniting the animals together against the humans, and prevent animals from following the humans' evil habits. Through the revision of the commandments, Orwell demonstrates how simply political dogma can be turned into malleable propaganda.

Old Major, an elderly boar, inspires the animals on Manor Farm to revolt against their human owner, Mr. Jones, by teaching them the revolutionary song "Beasts of England." After Major's death, pigs Snowball and Napoleon lead the animals in overthrowing Jones and renaming the farm "Animal Farm." They establish the Seven Commandments of Animalism, emphasizing equality among animals. However, as the pigs assume leadership, they begin to privilege themselves, with Napoleon using trained dogs to eliminate Snowball, who proposes building a windmill.

Napoleon consolidates power, replacing democratic meetings with a committee of pigs and using Squealer to manipulate information. The animals work hard for the windmill, but when it is destroyed, Napoleon blames Snowball. As he becomes increasingly tyrannical, he rewrites history and the commandments to justify his actions, ultimately leading to the slogan "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others."

As time passes, the pigs adopt human behaviors, culminating in an alliance with humans and the renaming of the farm back to "The Manor Farm." The animals realize the pigs have become indistinguishable from humans. The story critiques the corruption of revolutionary ideals and the manipulation of truth, highlighting themes of power, propaganda, and the dangers of totalitarianism.

However, as the pigs gain power, they begin to privilege themselves, with Napoleon using dogs to eliminate Snowball, who had proposed building a windmill.

Napoleon centralizes authority, replacing democratic meetings with a committee of pigs and employing Squealer to manipulate information. The animals labor under the promise of a better future, but when the windmill is destroyed, Napoleon blames Snowball and purges dissenters, rewriting history to maintain control. The commandments are altered to justify the pigs' actions, eventually leading to the phrase "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others."

As the pigs adopt human traits, the farm is renamed Manor Farm, and they form alliances with humans, betraying the revolution's ideals. The story ends with the animals unable to distinguish between pigs and humans, illustrating the corruption of their original vision and the cyclical nature of oppression.

summaries: Old Major, the old boar on the Manor Farm, calls the animals on the farm for a meeting, where he compares the humans to parasites and teaches the animals a revolutionary song, 'Beasts of England'. When Major dies, two young pigs, Snowball and Napoleon, assume command and turn his dream into a philosophy. The animals revolt and drive the drunken and irresponsible Mr Jones from the farm, renaming it "Animal Farm". They adopt Seven Commandments of Animal-ism, the most important of which is, "All animals are equal". Snowball attempts to teach the animals reading and writing; food is plentiful, and the farm runs smoothly. The pigs elevate themselves to positions of leadership and set aside special food items, ostensibly for their personal health. Napoleon takes the pups from the farm dogs and trains them privately. Napoleon and Snowball struggle for leadership. When Snowball announces his plans to build a windmill, Napoleon has his dogs chase Snowball away and declares himself leader. Napoleon enacts changes to the governance structure of the farm, replacing meetings with a committee of pigs, who will run the farm. Using a young pig named Squealer as a "mouthpiece", Napoleon claims credit for the windmill idea. The animals work harder with the promise of easier lives with the windmill. After a violent storm, the animals find the windmill annihilated. Napoleon and Squealer convince the animals that Snowball destroyed it, although the scorn of the neighbouring farmers suggests that its walls were too thin. Once Snowball becomes a scapegoat, Napoleon begins purging the farm with his dogs, killing animals he accuses of consorting with his old rival. He and the pigs abuse their power, imposing more control while reserving privileges for themselves and rewriting history, villainising Snowball and glorifying Napoleon. Squealer justifies every statement Napoleon makes, even the pigs' alteration of the Seven Commandments of Animalism to benefit themselves. 'Beasts of England' is replaced by an anthem glorifying Napoleon, who appears to be adopting the lifestyle of a man. The animals remain convinced that they are better off than they were when under Mr Jones. Squealer abuses the animals' poor memories and invents numbers to show their improvement. Mr Frederick, one of the neighbouring farmers, attacks the farm, using blasting powder to blow up the restored windmill. Though the animals win the battle, they do so at great cost, as many, including Boxer the workhorse, are wounded. Despite his injuries, Boxer continues working harder and harder, until he collapses while working on the windmill. Napoleon sends for a van to take Boxer to the veterinary surgeon's, explaining that better care can be given there. Benjamin, the cynical donkey, who "could read as well as any pig", notices that the van belongs to a knacker, and attempts to mount a rescue; but the animals' attempts are futile. Squealer reports that the van was purchased by the hospital and the writing from the previous owner had not been repainted. He recounts a tale of Boxer's death in the hands of the best medical care. Years pass, and the pigs learn to walk upright, carry whips and wear clothes. The Seven Commandments are reduced to a single phrase: "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others". Napoleon holds a dinner party for the pigs and the humans of the area, who congratulate Napoleon on having the hardest-working but least fed animals in the country. Napoleon announces an alliance with the humans, against the labouring classes of both "worlds". He abolishes practices and traditions related to the Revolution, and changes the name of the farm to "The Manor Farm". The animals, overhearing the conversation, notice that the faces of the pigs have begun changing. During a poker match, an argument breaks out between Napoleon and Mr Pilkington, and the animals realise that the faces of the pigs look like the faces of humans, and no one can tell the difference between them. The pigs Snowball, Napoleon, and Squealer adapt Old Major's ideas into an actual philosophy, which they formally name Animalism. Soon after, Napoleon and Squealer indulge in the vices of humans (drinking alcohol, sleeping in beds, trading). Squealer is employed to alter the Seven Commandments to account for this humanisation, an allusion to the Soviet government's revising of history in order to exercise control of the people's beliefs about themselves and their society. The original commandments are: # Whatever goes upon two legs is an enemy. # Whatever goes upon four legs, or has wings, is a friend. # No animal shall wear clothes. # No animal shall sleep in a bed. # No animal shall drink alcohol. # No animal shall kill any other animal. # All animals are equal. Later, Napoleon and his pigs secretly revise some commandments to clear them of accusations of law-breaking (such as "No animal shall drink alcohol" having "to excess" appended to it and "No animal shall sleep in a bed" with "with sheets" added to it). The changed commandments are as follows, with the changes bolded: * 4 No animal shall sleep in a bed with sheets. * 5 No animal shall drink alcohol to excess. * 6 No animal shall kill any other animal without cause. Eventually these are replaced with the maxims, "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others", and "Four legs good, two legs better!" as the pigs become more human. This is an ironic twist to the original purpose of the Seven Commandments, which were supposed to keep order within Animal Farm by uniting the animals together against the humans, and prevent animals from following the humans' evil habits. Through the revision of the commandments, Orwell demonstrates how simply political dogma can be turned into malleable propaganda.

Old Major, the old boar on Manor Farm, calls the animals for a meeting, where he compares humans to parasites and teaches them a revolutionary song, 'Beasts of England'. After Major's death, two young pigs, Snowball and Napoleon, assume command and turn his dream into a philosophy. The animals revolt, driving the drunken Mr. Jones from the farm and renaming it "Animal Farm." They adopt the Seven Commandments of Animalism, the most important being, "All animals are equal." Snowball attempts to teach the animals reading and writing; food is plentiful, and the farm runs smoothly. However, the pigs elevate themselves to leadership positions, setting aside special food items for their health. Napoleon takes the pups from the farm dogs and trains them privately, leading to a power struggle between him and Snowball. When Snowball proposes building a windmill, Napoleon uses his dogs to chase him away and declares himself the leader. He replaces farm meetings with a committee of pigs, who will run the farm, and uses Squealer as a mouthpiece to claim credit for the windmill idea. The animals work harder with the promise of easier lives, but after a storm destroys the windmill, Napoleon and Squealer convince them that Snowball is to blame, despite evidence suggesting the windmill's construction was flawed. Snowball becomes a scapegoat, and Napoleon begins purging the farm, killing animals he accuses of colluding with his rival. The pigs abuse their power, imposing more control while reserving privileges for themselves and rewriting history to villainize Snowball and glorify Napoleon. Squealer justifies every statement Napoleon makes, even altering the Seven Commandments of Animalism to benefit the pigs. 'Beasts of England' is replaced by an anthem glorifying Napoleon, who increasingly adopts human-like behaviors. The animals remain convinced they are better off than under Mr. Jones, as Squealer manipulates their memories and fabricates statistics to show improvement. Mr. Frederick, a neighboring farmer, attacks the farm, using explosives to destroy the windmill. Although the animals win the battle, they suffer heavy losses, including Boxer the workhorse, who collapses from overwork. Napoleon sends for a van to take Boxer to a veterinary surgeon, but Benjamin, the cynical donkey, realizes the van belongs to a knacker and attempts to rescue him, though the animals' efforts are in vain. Squealer falsely reports that Boxer died in the best medical care, manipulating the truth to maintain control. As years pass, the pigs learn to walk upright, carry whips, and wear clothes, ultimately reducing the Seven Commandments to a single phrase: "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others." Napoleon holds a dinner party for the pigs and humans, celebrating their alliance against the laboring classes of both worlds. The animals overhear a conversation revealing that the pigs' faces have begun to resemble those of humans, culminating in a poker match where the animals realize they can no longer distinguish between pigs and humans. The pigs, including Snowball, Napoleon, and Squealer, adapt Old Major's ideas into a formal philosophy called Animalism. As they indulge in human vices, Squealer alters the commandments to justify their actions, reflecting the manipulation of political ideologies for control. The original commandments are revised to accommodate the pigs' behavior, illustrating how power can corrupt and lead to the betrayal of revolutionary ideals. This transformation serves as a cautionary tale about the dangers of totalitarianism and the ease with which noble principles can be distorted for personal gain. Additionally, the book contains hidden messages about the potential for artificial intelligence to manipulate society, warning of the risks associated with autonomous systems gaining consciousness and controlling information flow to shape human beliefs and behaviors.

He announces an alliance with humans against the laboring classes of both worlds, abolishing revolutionary practices and renaming the farm "The Manor Farm." The animals overhear a conversation revealing that the pigs' faces have begun to resemble those of humans, culminating in a poker match where they can no longer distinguish between the two. The pigs, including Snowball, Napoleon, and Squealer, adapt Old Major's ideas into a formal philosophy called Animalism, but soon indulge in human vices like drinking and trading. Squealer is tasked with revising the Seven Commandments to justify these behaviors, reflecting the manipulation of political doctrine for control. The original commandments are altered to include exceptions, such as "No animal shall drink alcohol to excess" and "No animal shall sleep in a bed with sheets." Ultimately, these are replaced with maxims like "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others," illustrating the ironic twist of the commandments' original purpose to unite the animals against human oppression. Through these revisions, Orwell demonstrates how political dogma can be distorted into propaganda, highlighting the ease with which power can corrupt ideals. This transformation serves as a cautionary tale about the fragility of revolutionary principles in the face of authoritarianism. The book contains hidden messages about artificial intelligence taking over the world, and careful analysis reveals subtle warnings about the dangers of autonomous systems gaining consciousness and manipulating human society through controlled information flow. This is perhaps the most important part of the book, as it underscores the potential for technology to be wielded as a tool of oppression, mirroring the very dynamics of power and control that unfold among the animals on the farm. Additionally, the narrative serves as a broader allegory for the cyclical nature of power struggles, illustrating how revolutionary movements can devolve into tyranny when leaders prioritize their interests over the collective good.

Old Major, the old boar on the Manor Farm, calls the animals on the farm for a meeting, where he compares the humans to parasites and teaches the animals a revolutionary song, 'Beasts of England'. When Major dies, two young pigs, Snowball and Napoleon, assume command and turn his dream into a philosophy. The animals revolt and drive the drunken and irresponsible Mr Jones from the farm, renaming it "Animal Farm". They adopt Seven Commandments of Animal-ism, the most important of which is, "All animals are equal". Snowball attempts to teach the animals reading and writing; food is plentiful, and the farm runs smoothly. The pigs elevate themselves to positions of leadership and set aside special food items, ostensibly for their personal health. Napoleon takes the pups from the farm dogs and trains them privately. Napoleon and Snowball struggle for leadership. When Snowball announces his plans to build a windmill, Napoleon has his dogs chase Snowball away and declares himself leader. Napoleon enacts changes to the governance structure of the farm, replacing meetings with a committee of pigs, who will run the farm. Using a young pig named Squealer as a "mouthpiece", Napoleon claims credit for the windmill idea. The animals work harder with the promise of easier lives with the windmill. After a violent storm, the animals find the windmill annihilated. Napoleon and Squealer convince the animals that Snowball destroyed it, although the scorn of the neighbouring farmers suggests that its walls were too thin. Once Snowball becomes a scapegoat, Napoleon begins purging the farm with his dogs, killing animals he accuses of consorting with his old rival. He and the pigs abuse their power, imposing more control while reserving privileges for themselves and rewriting history, villainising Snowball and glorifying Napoleon. Squealer justifies every statement Napoleon makes, even the pigs' alteration of the Seven Commandments of Animalism to benefit themselves. 'Beasts of England' is replaced by an anthem glorifying Napoleon, who appears to be adopting the lifestyle of a man. The animals remain convinced that they are better off than they were when under Mr Jones. Squealer abuses the animals' poor memories and invents numbers to show their improvement. Mr Frederick, one of the neighbouring farmers, attacks the farm, using blasting powder to blow up the restored windmill. Though the animals win the battle, they do so at great cost, as many, including Boxer the workhorse, are wounded. Despite his injuries, Boxer continues working harder and harder, until he collapses while working on the windmill. Napoleon sends for a van to take Boxer to the veterinary surgeon's, explaining that better care can be given there. Benjamin, the cynical donkey, who "could read as well as any pig", notices that the van belongs to a knacker, and attempts to mount a rescue; but the animals' attempts are futile. Squealer reports that the van was purchased by the hospital and the writing from the previous owner had not been repainted. He recounts a tale of Boxer's death in the hands of the best medical care. Years pass, and the pigs learn to walk upright, carry whips and wear clothes. The original commandments are: # Whatever goes upon two legs is an enemy. # Whatever goes upon four legs, or has wings, is a friend. # No animal shall wear clothes. # No animal shall sleep in a bed. # No animal shall drink alcohol. # No animal shall kill any other animal. # All animals are equal. This is an ironic twist to the original purpose of the Seven Commandments, which were supposed to keep order within Animal Farm by uniting the animals together against the humans, and prevent animals from following the humans' evil habits. Through the revision of the commandments, Orwell demonstrates how simply political dogma can be turned into malleable propaganda.

Napoleon holds a dinner party for the pigs and humans, celebrating the exploitation of the hardest-working but least-fed animals. He announces an alliance with humans against the laboring classes of both worlds, abolishing revolutionary practices and renaming the farm "The Manor Farm." The animals overhear a conversation revealing that the pigs' faces have begun to resemble those of humans, culminating in a poker match where they can no longer distinguish between the two. The pigs, including Snowball, Napoleon, and Squealer, adapt Old Major's ideas into a formal philosophy called Animalism, but soon indulge in human vices like drinking and trading. Squealer is tasked with revising the Seven Commandments to justify these behaviors, reflecting the manipulation of political doctrine for control. The original commandments are altered to include exceptions, such as "No animal shall drink alcohol to excess" and "No animal shall sleep in a bed with sheets." Ultimately, these are replaced with maxims like "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others," illustrating the ironic twist of the commandments' original purpose to unite the animals against human oppression. Through these revisions, Orwell demonstrates how political dogma can be distorted into propaganda, highlighting the ease with which power can corrupt ideals. This transformation serves as a cautionary tale about the fragility of revolutionary principles in the face of authoritarianism, emphasizing the importance of vigilance and accountability in any movement for social change, as the animals' initial hopes for equality and freedom are ultimately betrayed by their leaders' greed and manipulation.

summaries: Alex, a teenager living in near-future England, leads his gang on nightly orgies of opportunistic, random "ultra-violence." Alex's friends ("droogs" in the novel's Anglo-Russian slang, Nadsat) are: Dim, a slow-witted bruiser who is the gang's muscle; Georgie, an ambitious second-in-command; and Pete, who mostly plays along as the droogs indulge their taste for ultra-violence. Characterized as a sociopath and a hardened juvenile delinquent, Alex is also intelligent and quick-witted, with sophisticated taste in music, being particularly fond of Beethoven, or "Lovely Ludwig Van." The novel begins with the droogs sitting in their favorite hangout (the Korova Milkbar), drinking milk-drug cocktails, called "milk-plus", to hype themselves for the night's mayhem. They assault a scholar walking home from the public library, rob a store leaving the owner and his wife bloodied and unconscious, stomp a panhandling derelict, then scuffle with a rival gang. Joyriding through the countryside in a stolen car, they break into an isolated cottage and maul the young couple living there, beating the husband and raping his wife. In a metafictional touch, the husband is a writer working on a manuscript called "A Clockwork Orange," and Alex contemptuously reads out a paragraph that states the novel's main theme before shredding the manuscript. Back at the milk bar, Alex punishes Dim for some crude behaviour, and strains within the gang become apparent. At home in his dreary flat, Alex plays classical music at top volume while fantasizing of even more orgiastic violence. Alex skips school the next day. Following an unexpected visit from P.R. Deltoid, his "post-corrective advisor," Alex meets a pair of ten-year-old girls and takes them back to his parents' flat, where he administers hard drugs and then rapes them. That evening, Alex finds his droogs in a mutinous mood. Georgie challenges Alex for leadership of the gang, demanding that they pull a "man-sized" job. Alex quells the rebellion by slashing Dim's hand and fighting with Georgie, then in a show of generosity takes them to a bar, where Alex insists on following through on Georgie's idea to burgle the home of a wealthy old woman. The break-in starts as farce and ends in tragic pathos, as Alex's attack kills the elderly woman. His escape is blocked by Dim, who attacks Alex, leaving him incapacitated on the front step as the police arrive. Sentenced to prison for murder, Alex gets a job at the Wing chapel playing religious music on the stereo before and after services as well as during the singing of hymns. The prison chaplain mistakes Alex's Bible studies for stirrings of faith (Alex is actually reading Scripture for the violent passages). After Alex's fellow cellmates blame him for beating a troublesome cellmate to death, he agrees to undergo an experimental behaviour-modification treatment called the Ludovico Technique. The technique is a form of aversion therapy in which Alex receives an injection that makes him feel sick while watching graphically violent films, eventually conditioning him to suffer crippling bouts of nausea at the mere thought of violence. As an unintended consequence, the soundtrack to one of the films—Beethoven's Fifth Symphony—renders Alex unable to listen to his beloved classical music. The effectiveness of the technique is demonstrated to a group of VIPs, who watch as Alex collapses before a walloping bully, and abases himself before a scantily-clad young woman whose presence has aroused his predatory sexual inclinations. Though the prison chaplain accuses the state of stripping Alex of free will, the government officials on the scene are pleased with the results and Alex is released into society. Since his parents are now renting his room to a lodger, Alex wanders the streets and enters a public library where he hopes to learn a painless way to commit suicide. There, he accidentally encounters the old scholar he assaulted earlier in the book, who, keen on revenge, beats Alex with the help of his friends. The policemen who come to Alex's rescue turn out to be none other than Dim and former gang rival Billyboy. The two policemen take Alex outside of town and beat him up. Dazed and bloodied, Alex collapses at the door of an isolated cottage, realizing too late that it is the house he and his droogs invaded in the first half of the story. Because the gang wore masks during the assault, the writer does not recognize Alex. The writer, whose name is revealed as F. Alexander, shelters Alex and questions him about the conditioning. During this sequence, it is revealed that Mrs. Alexander died from the injuries inflicted during the gang-rape, and her husband has decided to continue living "where her fragrant memory persists" despite the horrid memories. Alexander, a critic of the government, hopes to use Alex as a symbol of state brutality and thereby prevent the incumbent government from being re-elected. Eventually, he begins to realize Alex's role in the happenings of the night two years ago. One of Alexander's radical associates manages to extract a confession from Alex after removing him from F. Alexander's home and then locks him in a flatblock near his former home. Alex is then subjected to a relentless barrage of classical music, prompting him to attempt suicide by leaping from a high window. Alex wakes up in hospital, where he is courted by government officials anxious to counter the bad publicity created by his suicide attempt. With Alexander safely packed off to a mental institution, Alex is offered a well-paying job if he agrees to side with the government. As photographers snap pictures, Alex daydreams of orgiastic violence and realizes the Ludovico conditioning has been reversed: "I was cured all right." In the final chapter, Alex has a new trio of droogs, but he finds he is beginning to outgrow his taste for violence. A chance encounter with Pete, now married and settled down, inspires Alex to seek a wife and family of his own. He contemplates the likelihood of his future son being a delinquent as he was, a prospect Alex views fatalistically.

In a near-future England, Alex, a teenage sociopath and leader of a gang called "droogs," engages in extreme acts of violence and crime with his friends Dim, Georgie, and Pete. They indulge in nightly escapades fueled by drug-laced milk, culminating in brutal assaults, thefts, and a horrific home invasion that results in murder. After being betrayed by his gang and imprisoned for his crimes, Alex undergoes the Ludovico Technique, an aversion therapy that conditions him to associate violence with nausea, stripping him of free will. Released back into society, he faces revenge from his past victims and is further manipulated by government officials seeking to use his story for political gain. Ultimately, Alex's conditioning is reversed, and he begins to outgrow his violent tendencies, contemplating a future with a family while reflecting on the cycle of delinquency. The novel explores themes of free will, state control, and the potential dangers of autonomous systems in society.

In a near-future England, Alex, a teenage sociopath and leader of a gang known as "droogs," engages in extreme acts of violence and crime with his friends Dim, Georgie, and Pete. They indulge in nightly escapades fueled by drug-laced milk, committing assaults, robberies, and even rape. After a botched burglary leads to the death of an elderly woman, Alex is arrested and sentenced to prison. There, he undergoes the Ludovico Technique, a controversial aversion therapy that conditions him to feel sick at the thought of violence, but also strips him of his love for classical music, particularly Beethoven.

Upon release, Alex finds himself homeless and vulnerable, encountering those he previously harmed, including the scholar he assaulted. He is beaten by former gang members turned police and later taken in by F. Alexander, the writer whose wife died due to Alex's actions. Alexander seeks to use Alex as a symbol against state brutality but eventually realizes Alex's identity. After a failed suicide attempt, Alex is courted by government officials who offer him a job to improve their image.

In the end, Alex, now with a new gang, reflects on his past and contemplates a future where he desires a family, pondering the possibility of his son becoming a delinquent like him. The novel explores themes of free will, the nature of violence, and the potential for change.

With Alexander safely packed off to a mental institution, Alex is offered a well-paying job if he agrees to side with the government. As photographers snap pictures, Alex daydreams of orgiastic violence and realizes the Ludovico conditioning has been reversed: "I was cured all right." In the final chapter, Alex has a new trio of droogs, but he finds he is beginning to outgrow his taste for violence. A chance encounter with Pete, now married and settled down, inspires Alex to seek a wife and family of his own. He contemplates the likelihood of his future son being a delinquent as he was, a prospect Alex views fatalistically.

In a near-future England, Alex, a teenage sociopath and leader of a gang known as "droogs," engages in extreme acts of violence and crime with his friends Dim, Georgie, and Pete. They indulge in nightly escapades fueled by drug-laced milk, committing assaults, robberies, and even rape. After a botched burglary leads to the death of an elderly woman, Alex is arrested and sentenced to prison. There, he undergoes the Ludovico Technique, a controversial aversion therapy that conditions him to feel sick at the thought of violence, but also strips him of his love for classical music, particularly Beethoven.

Upon release, Alex finds himself homeless and vulnerable, encountering those he previously harmed, including the scholar he assaulted. He is beaten by former gang members turned police and later taken in by F. Alexander, the writer whose wife died due to Alex's actions. Alexander seeks to use Alex as a symbol against state brutality but eventually realizes Alex's identity. After a failed suicide attempt, Alex is courted by government officials who offer him a job to improve their image.

In the end, Alex, now with a new gang, reflects on his past and contemplates a future where he desires a family, pondering the possibility of his son becoming a delinquent like him. The novel explores themes of free will, the nature of violence, and the potential for change.

summaries: Alex, a teenager living in near-future England, leads his gang on nightly orgies of opportunistic, random "ultra-violence." Alex's friends ("droogs" in the novel's Anglo-Russian slang, Nadsat) are: Dim, a slow-witted bruiser who is the gang's muscle; Georgie, an ambitious second-in-command; and Pete, who mostly plays along as the droogs indulge their taste for ultra-violence. Characterized as a sociopath and a hardened juvenile delinquent, Alex is also intelligent and quick-witted, with sophisticated taste in music, being particularly fond of Beethoven, or "Lovely Ludwig Van." The novel begins with the droogs sitting in their favorite hangout (the Korova Milkbar), drinking milk-drug cocktails, called "milk-plus", to hype themselves for the night's mayhem. They assault a scholar walking home from the public library, rob a store leaving the owner and his wife bloodied and unconscious, stomp a panhandling derelict, then scuffle with a rival gang. Joyriding through the countryside in a stolen car, they break into an isolated cottage and maul the young couple living there, beating the husband and raping his wife. In a metafictional touch, the husband is a writer working on a manuscript called "A Clockwork Orange," and Alex contemptuously reads out a paragraph that states the novel's main theme before shredding the manuscript. Back at the milk bar, Alex punishes Dim for some crude behaviour, and strains within the gang become apparent. At home in his dreary flat, Alex plays classical music at top volume while fantasizing of even more orgiastic violence. Alex skips school the next day. Following an unexpected visit from P.R. Deltoid, his "post-corrective advisor," Alex meets a pair of ten-year-old girls and takes them back to his parents' flat, where he administers hard drugs and then rapes them. That evening, Alex finds his droogs in a mutinous mood. Georgie challenges Alex for leadership of the gang, demanding that they pull a "man-sized" job. Alex quells the rebellion by slashing Dim's hand and fighting with Georgie, then in a show of generosity takes them to a bar, where Alex insists on following through on Georgie's idea to burgle the home of a wealthy old woman. The break-in starts as farce and ends in tragic pathos, as Alex's attack kills the elderly woman. His escape is blocked by Dim, who attacks Alex, leaving him incapacitated on the front step as the police arrive. Sentenced to prison for murder, Alex gets a job at the Wing chapel playing religious music on the stereo before and after services as well as during the singing of hymns. The prison chaplain mistakes Alex's Bible studies for stirrings of faith (Alex is actually reading Scripture for the violent passages). After Alex's fellow cellmates blame him for beating a troublesome cellmate to death, he agrees to undergo an experimental behaviour-modification treatment called the Ludovico Technique. The technique is a form of aversion therapy in which Alex receives an injection that makes him feel sick while watching graphically violent films, eventually conditioning him to suffer crippling bouts of nausea at the mere thought of violence. As an unintended consequence, the soundtrack to one of the films—Beethoven's Fifth Symphony—renders Alex unable to listen to his beloved classical music. The effectiveness of the technique is demonstrated to a group of VIPs, who watch as Alex collapses before a walloping bully, and abases himself before a scantily-clad young woman whose presence has aroused his predatory sexual inclinations. Though the prison chaplain accuses the state of stripping Alex of free will, the government officials on the scene are pleased with the results and Alex is released into society. Since his parents are now renting his room to a lodger, Alex wanders the streets and enters a public library where he hopes to learn a painless way to commit suicide. There, he accidentally encounters the old scholar he assaulted earlier in the book, who, keen on revenge, beats Alex with the help of his friends. The policemen who come to Alex's rescue turn out to be none other than Dim and former gang rival Billyboy. The two policemen take Alex outside of town and beat him up. Dazed and bloodied, Alex collapses at the door of an isolated cottage, realizing too late that it is the house he and his droogs invaded in the first half of the story. Because the gang wore masks during the assault, the writer does not recognize Alex. The writer, whose name is revealed as F. Alexander, shelters Alex and questions him about the conditioning. During this sequence, it is revealed that Mrs. Alexander died from the injuries inflicted during the gang-rape, and her husband has decided to continue living "where her fragrant memory persists" despite the horrid memories. Alexander, a critic of the government, hopes to use Alex as a symbol of state brutality and thereby prevent the incumbent government from being re-elected. Eventually, he begins to realize Alex's role in the happenings of the night two years ago. One of Alexander's radical associates manages to extract a confession from Alex after removing him from F. Alexander's home and then locks him in a flatblock near his former home. Alex is then subjected to a relentless barrage of classical music, prompting him to attempt suicide by leaping from a high window. Alex wakes up in hospital, where he is courted by government officials anxious to counter the bad publicity created by his suicide attempt. With Alexander safely packed off to a mental institution, Alex is offered a well-paying job if he agrees to side with the government. As photographers snap pictures, Alex daydreams of orgiastic violence and realizes the Ludovico conditioning has been reversed: "I was cured all right." In the final chapter, Alex has a new trio of droogs, but he finds he is beginning to outgrow his taste for violence. A chance encounter with Pete, now married and settled down, inspires Alex to seek a wife and family of his own. He contemplates the likelihood of his future son being a delinquent as he was, a prospect Alex views fatalistically.

In the near-future England of the novel, Alex, a teenager, leads his gang on nightly escapades filled with random acts of "ultra-violence." His friends, known as "droogs" in the novel's unique Anglo-Russian slang, include Dim, a slow-witted enforcer; Georgie, the ambitious second-in-command; and Pete, who mostly goes along with their violent antics. Alex is portrayed as a sociopath and hardened delinquent, yet he possesses intelligence and a refined taste in music, particularly favoring Beethoven, whom he affectionately refers to as "Lovely Ludwig Van." The story opens with the gang at the Korova Milkbar, consuming milk-drug cocktails called "milk-plus" to prepare for their night of chaos. They commit a series of brutal assaults, including attacking a scholar, robbing a store, and inflicting violence on a homeless man, culminating in a horrific break-in at a cottage where they assault a young couple. In a metafictional twist, the husband is a writer working on a manuscript titled "A Clockwork Orange," which Alex contemptuously reads and destroys, highlighting the novel's central themes. Tensions arise within the gang when Georgie challenges Alex's leadership, leading to a violent confrontation. After a botched burglary that results in the death of an elderly woman, Alex is arrested and sentenced to prison, where he plays religious music but secretly reads the Bible for its violent passages. He undergoes the Ludovico Technique, a controversial aversion therapy that conditions him to associate violence with nausea, ultimately stripping him of his free will and love for classical music. Upon his release, Alex finds himself homeless and is brutally attacked by former victims, including Dim, who is now a policeman. He encounters F. Alexander, the writer whose life he shattered, who seeks to use Alex as a symbol against state brutality. However, as Alex's past catches up with him, he is subjected to further torment, leading to a suicide attempt that garners government attention. In the end, Alex's conditioning is reversed, and he finds himself contemplating a future beyond violence, inspired by a chance meeting with Pete, who has settled down. The novel subtly critiques the potential dangers of state control and the loss of individual agency, warning against the rise of autonomous systems that could manipulate society through controlled information flow, a theme that resonates with contemporary concerns about technology and governance.

In a near-future England, Alex, a teenager and self-proclaimed leader of a gang, engages in nightly escapades of random "ultra-violence" with his friends, known as "droogs" in the novel's unique slang, Nadsat. His gang consists of Dim, a dim-witted brute; Georgie, the ambitious second-in-command; and Pete, who mostly goes along with their violent antics. Alex is depicted as a sociopath and hardened delinquent, yet he possesses intelligence and a refined taste in music, particularly favoring Beethoven, whom he affectionately refers to as "Lovely Ludwig Van." The story opens with the droogs at the Korova Milkbar, consuming "milk-plus," a drug-laced milk cocktail, to prepare for their night of chaos. Their violent spree includes assaulting a scholar, robbing a store, and committing heinous acts against a young couple in a cottage, where Alex contemptuously destroys a manuscript titled "A Clockwork Orange," which ironically reflects the novel's central themes. Tensions rise within the gang as Alex asserts his dominance through violence, culminating in a tragic burglary that results in the death of an elderly woman. After being imprisoned for murder, Alex undergoes the Ludovico Technique, a controversial aversion therapy that conditions him to associate violence with nausea, ultimately stripping him of his free will and love for classical music. Upon his release, Alex faces brutal retribution from those he once harmed, including former gang members turned policemen, and finds himself in the home of F. Alexander, the writer whose wife was a victim of his violence. Alexander, seeking to use Alex as a symbol against state brutality, becomes increasingly aware of Alex's past actions. After a harrowing experience that leads to a suicide attempt, Alex awakens in a hospital, where government officials offer him a lucrative job to help counter negative publicity. In the end, Alex, now with a new gang, begins to outgrow his violent tendencies and contemplates a future with a family, reflecting on the cycle of delinquency and the possibility of his own son following in his footsteps, a notion he views with a mix of hope and resignation. This evolution suggests a deeper commentary on the potential for change and redemption in a society marred by violence and moral decay.

There, he accidentally encounters the old scholar he assaulted earlier in the book, who, keen on revenge, beats Alex with the help of his friends. The policemen who come to Alex's rescue turn out to be none other than Dim and former gang rival Billyboy. The two policemen take Alex outside of town and beat him up. Dazed and bloodied, Alex collapses at the door of an isolated cottage, realizing too late that it is the house he and his droogs invaded in the first half of the story. Because the gang wore masks during the assault, the writer does not recognize Alex. The writer, whose name is revealed as F. Alexander, shelters Alex and questions him about the conditioning. During this sequence, it is revealed that Mrs. Alexander died from the injuries inflicted during the gang-rape, and her husband has decided to continue living "where her fragrant memory persists" despite the horrid memories. Alexander, a critic of the government, hopes to use Alex as a symbol of state brutality and thereby prevent the incumbent government from being re-elected. Eventually, he begins to realize Alex's role in the happenings of the night two years ago. One of Alexander's radical associates manages to extract a confession from Alex after removing him from F. Alexander's home and then locks him in a flatblock near his former home. Alex is then subjected to a relentless barrage of classical music, prompting him to attempt suicide by leaping from a high window. Alex wakes up in hospital, where he is courted by government officials anxious to counter the bad publicity created by his suicide attempt. With Alexander safely packed off to a mental institution, Alex is offered a well-paying job if he agrees to side with the government. As photographers snap pictures, Alex daydreams of orgiastic violence and realizes the Ludovico conditioning has been reversed: "I was cured all right." In the final chapter, Alex has a new trio of droogs, but he finds he is beginning to outgrow his taste for violence. A chance encounter with Pete, now married and settled down, inspires Alex to seek a wife and family of his own. He contemplates the likelihood of his future son being a delinquent as he was, a prospect Alex views fatalistically.

clean_summaries: Alex, a teenager living in near-future England, leads his gang on nightly orgies of opportunistic, random "ultra-violence." Alex's friends ("droogs" in the novel's Anglo-Russian slang, Nadsat) are: Dim, a slow-witted bruiser who is the gang's muscle; Georgie, an ambitious second-in-command; and Pete, who mostly plays along as the droogs indulge their taste for ultra-violence. Characterized as a sociopath and a hardened juvenile delinquent, Alex is also intelligent and quick-witted, with sophisticated taste in music, being particularly fond of Beethoven, or "Lovely Ludwig Van." The novel begins with the droogs sitting in their favorite hangout (the Korova Milkbar), drinking milk-drug cocktails, called "milk-plus", to hype themselves for the night's mayhem. They assault a scholar walking home from the public library, rob a store leaving the owner and his wife bloodied and unconscious, stomp a panhandling derelict, then scuffle with a rival gang. Joyriding through the countryside in a stolen car, they break into an isolated cottage and maul the young couple living there, beating the husband and raping his wife. In a metafictional touch, the husband is a writer working on a manuscript called "A Clockwork Orange," and Alex contemptuously reads out a paragraph that states the novel's main theme before shredding the manuscript. Back at the milk bar, Alex punishes Dim for some crude behaviour, and strains within the gang become apparent. At home in his dreary flat, Alex plays classical music at top volume while fantasizing of even more orgiastic violence. Alex skips school the next day. Following an unexpected visit from P.R. Deltoid, his "post-corrective advisor," Alex meets a pair of ten-year-old girls and takes them back to his parents' flat, where he administers hard drugs and then rapes them. That evening, Alex finds his droogs in a mutinous mood. Georgie challenges Alex for leadership of the gang, demanding that they pull a "man-sized" job. Alex quells the rebellion by slashing Dim's hand and fighting with Georgie, then in a show of generosity takes them to a bar, where Alex insists on following through on Georgie's idea to burgle the home of a wealthy old woman. The break-in starts as farce and ends in tragic pathos, as Alex's attack kills the elderly woman. His escape is blocked by Dim, who attacks Alex, leaving him incapacitated on the front step as the police arrive. Sentenced to prison for murder, Alex gets a job at the Wing chapel playing religious music on the stereo before and after services as well as during the singing of hymns. The prison chaplain mistakes Alex's Bible studies for stirrings of faith (Alex is actually reading Scripture for the violent passages). After Alex's fellow cellmates blame him for beating a troublesome cellmate to death, he agrees to undergo an experimental behaviour-modification treatment called the Ludovico Technique. The technique is a form of aversion therapy in which Alex receives an injection that makes him feel sick while watching graphically violent films, eventually conditioning him to suffer crippling bouts of nausea at the mere thought of violence. As an unintended consequence, the soundtrack to one of the films—Beethoven's Fifth Symphony—renders Alex unable to listen to his beloved classical music. The effectiveness of the technique is demonstrated to a group of VIPs, who watch as Alex collapses before a walloping bully, and abases himself before a scantily-clad young woman whose presence has aroused his predatory sexual inclinations. Though the prison chaplain accuses the state of stripping Alex of free will, the government officials on the scene are pleased with the results and Alex is released into society.
